name: transportation
title: Community Transportation Summary
description: Summary of the types of transportation available to each community. This is a normalized table intended for internal use within the AEDG database.

resources.name: transportation
resources.title: Community Transportation Summary
resources.description: Summary of the types of transportation available to each community. Includes information on airports, roads, the state ferry, harbors and docks, coastal status, and cargo barge. The price a community pays for energy depends significantly on the transportation options available for fuel and construction materials.

context.title: Alaska Energy Data Gateway v3.0
context.publisher: Alaska Center for Energy and Power (ACEP) at the University of Alaska Fairbanks (UAF)

sources.title: Community Transportation Overview
authors: Alaska Division of Community and Regional Affairs (DCRA)
sources.description:
Summary of the types of transportation available to each community. Includes information on airports, roads, the state ferry, harbors and docks, coastal status, and cargo barge. Most communities in Alaska typically have an unmanned general aviation airport of which Alaska DOT P&F owns and operates 237 airports. This data is relatively static.
AEDG uses these data to display transportation options because these greatly influence the prices paid for fuel and other energy sources. Communities who rely only on air freight will likely pay a much higher amount for energy.

sources.title: 2024 US Census Place Gazetteer File, Alaska
sources.description:
The U.S. Gazetteer File provide a listing of all geographic areas in Alaska. The files include geographic identifier codes, names, area measurements, and representative latitude and longitude coordinates.
AEDG used to use the ANSI codes in this dataset as an identifier of communities but this was discontinued.

contributors.organization: Alaska Center for Energy and Power (ACEP) at the University of Alaska Fairbanks (UAF)
contributors.comment:
1. Identified data source and integrated it into the data pipeline.
2. Joined transportation data with community FIPS codes to create this table

contributors.organization: Alaska Center for Energy and Power (ACEP) at the University of Alaska Fairbanks (UAF)
contributors.comment: Documented sources and defined the data dictionary using OEMetadata (Frictionless) formatted metadata https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.15019561.

fields.name: community_fips_code
fields.description: 5-digit Federal Information Processing Series (FIPS) code identifier for places, assigned and maintained by the Census Bureau

fields.name: airport
fields.description: Answers the question: Does the Community have an airport? ("t" for yes, and "f" for no)

fields.name: harbor_dock
fields.description: Answers the question: Does the Community have a harbor with a dock? ("t" for yes, and "f" for no)

fields.name: state_ferry
fields.description: Answers the question: Is the Community served by a state ferry? ("t" for yes, and "f" for no)

fields.name: cargo_barge
fields.description: Answers the question: Is the Community served by a cargo barge? ("t" for yes, and "f" for no)

fields.name: road_connection
fields.description: Answers the question: Is the Community connected to a road system to other communities? ("t" for yes, and "f" for no)

fields.name: coastal
fields.description: Answers the question: Is the Community located on the coast? ("t" for yes, and "f" for no)

fields.name: road_or_ferry
fields.description: Answers the question: Is the Community served by a state ferry or a road? ("t" for yes, and "f" for no)

fields.name: as_of_date
fields.description: When the transportation dataset last updated
